DataElement.preferredName: Fluorescence in situ Hybridization Cytogenetics Abnormal Interphase Nucleus Result Count
DataElement.preferredDefinition: a numeric value counting atypical cell nuclei (organelles) captured in the interval between mitoses as an outcome from lab procedure to map chromosomes using fluorescent tags and detect abnormalities.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Fluorescence in situ Hybridization Cytogenetics Abnormal Interphase Nucleus Result
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: related to atypical cell nuclei (organelles) captured in the interval between cell divisions as the outcome from a lab procedure to map chromosomes using fluorescent tags and detect abnormalities.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A type of IN SITU HYBRIDIZATION in which target sequences are stained with fluorescent dye so their location and size can be determined using fluorescence microscopy. This staining is sufficiently distinct that the hybridization signal can be seen both in metaphase spreads and in interphase nuclei.:Cytogenetics is the study of chromosomes and the related disease states caused by numerical and structural chromosome abnormalities.

Concepts.definition: A physical mapping approach that uses fluorescent tags to detect hybridization of probes within metaphase chromosomes or less condensed somatic interphase chromatin. This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping.
The branch of biology that studies the cellular aspects of heredity, especially the chromosomes. Includes the study of disease states caused by numerical and structural chromosome abnormalities.

Property.preferredDefinition: Deviating from the norm.:The interval between two successive cell divisions during which the chromosomes are not individually distinguishable. Interphase is considered the resting stage of the cell.:Within a eukaryotic cell, a membrane-limited body which contains chromosomes and one or more nucleoli (CELL NUCLEOLUS). The nuclear membrane consists of a double unit-type membrane which is perforated by a number of pores; the outermost membrane is continuous with the ENDOPLASMIC RETICULUM. A cell may contain more than one nucleus. (From Singleton & Sainsbury, Dictionary of Microbiology and Molecular Biology, 2d ed):Outcome; a phenomenon that follows and is caused by some previous phenomenon.

Concepts.definition: Deviating in any way from the state, position, structure, condition, behavior, or rule which is considered a norm.
The interval between two successive cell divisions during which the chromosomes are not individually distinguishable. Interphase is considered the resting stage of the cell.
A body within the cell, surrounded by a membrane, within which lie the chromosomes, one or more nucleoli, combined with proteins, and exhibits mitosis.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Fluorescence in situ Hybridization Cytogenetics Nucleus Result Count
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: a numeric value counting the organelles within cells that contain genetic material as an outcome from a laboratory procedure which maps chromosomes using fluorescent tags to detect abnormalities.

Concepts.definition: Determining the number or amount of something.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: new version to correct incorrect use of Rep term
